On Mon, 3 Mar 2003, Seairth Jacobs wrote:

> This topic has been in some of the threads lately, as well as in other
> similar topics (see distributed-registry thread about Meta-Query).  How do
> you go about, in a RESTful manner, returning different representations of
> the same resource when those representations have the same content-type?
> Admittedly, this is not a common case these days, but I think such a
> scenario will become more frequent.
>
> As mentioned in a couple posts, a common technique is to use a query string
> to distinquish.  Another technique is to treat the variants as a sort of
> sub-resource.  Both of these techniques have their advantages and
> disadvantages.  However, the one disadvantage they both have is that they
> are in no way standardized across implementations.  For instance, Jeff Bone,
> Joe Gregorio, and I use different query strings for serving up RSS.
>
> One of the nice things about MIME types is that they are "standardized",
> hence the Accept header.  But that is course-grained.  For instance, there
> is no way using Accept: to indicate whether the client wants to receive RSS
> 0.91 or RSS 2.0.  Sure, we could register more and more content-types, but
> that seems like a nightmare (though I gather some work is being done to
> address such a problem).
>
> So what is a RESTful app to do?
>
